Author: cheeweon#5786
Content: i  heard to be listed on bdex or hyperdex , token or coin must be bitcoin-based. i cant understand what ‚Äúbitcoin-based‚Äù  means.  for example stellar is not be bitcoin-based?

Author: cipi#4502
Content:
"bitcoin-based" means the wallet has a RPC-API with this calls: https://bitcoin.org/en/developer-reference#bitcoin-core-apis
so calls like "gettxout", "importaddress", "sendrawtransaction" and so on are supported...
btw. ERC20-stuff works too

Author: cheeweon#5786
Content: @cipi i am not a pro dev. so i cant understand it .  generally centralized exchanges are listing many coins or tokens like stellar,btc  etc  .  bdex is limited ?   i have a coin - on testnet currently, mainnet q4 2018 , not erc 20 token-  that want to list on bdex .

Author: cipi#4502
Content: yes, BarterDEX is limited, because it must deal with every coin in part, so every trade on BarterDEX is onchain, means transactions are made on the blockchains of the involved coins... means BarterDEX must know how to create transactions of the coins... centralized exchanges do nothing onchain, in fact you are not even trading coins there, only some database entries and you must trust them that the coins you trade there really exist and are not only database entries üòÉ

Author: cheeweon#5786
Content: i understood  what   you mean. so is not stellar bitcoin-based? if yes then stellar cant be listed ever?

Author: cipi#4502
Content: no, unfortunately not... else, i had integrated it a long time ago üòÉ if it will be possible to ever list it, is another question, but i don't know the answer, @jl777c has to answer this

Author: cheeweon#5786
Content: what questions should i ask dev of project that i want to list on bdex?

Author: cipi#4502
Content:
if he wants to integrate a ERC20-token, the contract must be really ERC20 (not ERC223)  and it must have the methods "approve" and "transferFrom" (99% of ERC20 have this)
if he wants to integrate a bitcoin-RPC-compatible coin, the wallet must support some basic calls, like "gettxout" and "importaddress" and it must have BIP65 activated: https://github.com/bitcoin/bips/blob/master/bip-0065.mediawiki

Author: cipi#4502
Content: we will have to test each coin in part, to be sure it is working

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: in theory ripple and stellar could be supported as long as they have multisig

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: support via ILP might be a more practical way

Author: monokh#4656
Content:
Hi, i found the HyperDex really interesting, i had a few questions
- i notice it uses these "SuperNET" node. what is this? does it have any implications for centralisation?  i couldn't find any details about this software
- Is it using a true chain to chain atomic swap? I.e. as a user i hold my own private key and i can execute the swap using my own block chain nodes?

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: HyperDex uses electrum servers, so you hold the private keys, but the transacton is broadcast on a server so you dont need the entire blockchain. BarterDEX supports Native coins.

Author: monokh#4656
Content: thanks @blackjok3r  is there no dependency on komodo? If i'm trading bitcoin to litecoin for example, does anyone of the process hit the komodo blockchain?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: KMD is not needed

Author: monokh#4656
Content: thanks @jl777c  as you developed the Supernet library, would you mind  explaining it's function? It is a pretty large library but i cannot find any info on what it's role is in the atomic swaps

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: it implements all but the low level crypto libraries

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: all the atomic swaps, rawtransaction handling, networking, orderbooks, api, etc.

Author: monokh#4656
Content:
i see, so with this library, I could technically run my own barterdex with orderbooks etc. with the use of the supernet node? 
there aren't any centralised points of information that the barterdex/hyperdex needs?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: correct. you could setup marketmakers on one of the 14000+ netids and not use any of the existing barterDEX infrastructure

Author: monokh#4656
Content: that's really amazing...

Author: monokh#4656
Content: but what really is the incentive for the developers? i noticed there is a fee involved, how do you setup which person can take the fee?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: the dexfee goes to a special address

Author: monokh#4656
Content: at which level is the fee defined? The ui application which facilitates the transfer i.e. barterdex/hyperdex or the network like supernet?

Author: jl777c#5810
Content: built into the atomic swap protocol
